div.div: Given that these two variables go in similar directions, there will be an independent variable resulting from their interactions in this direction

switch.text: Given that these two variables go in simila...

switch.text: Some independent variable, like a simple...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 58px; height: 1px; padding-top: 346px; margin-left: 430px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 415px; height: 1px; padding-top: 601px; margin-left: 354px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Now that we know some of the structure in this direction (the variable created by the interactions of simplicity/linearity) we can expect that variable to be relevant to changes in that direction, and connect them to our current position (connect that variable to our current position represented by the circle, using the green arrow), which gives us more info about whether that variable/direction will be useful for some solution metric (the purple arrow), arriving at a midpoint representing a ratio of computation indicating higher certainty whether this direction will be more/less useful.
Identifying all the intersections of these independent variables by extending the dotted lines until they intersect is possible and useful across problems.
This is a 'specific set of variables' that, when connected, can be used to derive all other connections. (All other variable connections will be less independent than these independent connections).

switch.text: Now that we know some of the structure in this direction (the variabl...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 309px; height: 1px; padding-top: 451px; margin-left: 1px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
If a square is iterated, it encounters an independent variable, which is an additional dimension of a stack.
So in the direction of the "iteration" variable, we can identify independent variables.
How do you identify that in this direction (iteration), an independent variable like dimensionality will become determining? (How to find the intersections/limits/structures of independence that will create these useful green arrows which are useful for finding these orange points which are useful for filtering directions of change?)

switch.text: If a square is iterated, it encounters an independen...

div.div: Independent variable networks to solve problems of 'identifying useful directions of change'
